results.content:
Before taking up this course, I have read reviews on both ends (5 stars, 2 stars & 1 star). While not everything is covered, I would say this course is meant to kickstart your learning and understanding of TDD and unit testing, especially if you are completely new. And I am confident to say that this course is well-scoped and suffice in building one's foundation and having a big picture.  

After completing the course, it has helped to bridge some gaps and understanding of how unit testing works, especially in the area of mocking values. While my projects don't really just do CRUD operations, I am able to take actionable steps to apply what I have learnt into my projects. Considering that the Jest documentation can be quite foreign if you are new, going through this course let me go beyond to continue learning and understanding Jest and mocking in particular.

Feedback: Will be good to occasionally check if the services suggested to use is still applicable. For example, the DB cloud service used which is mLab, is now part of MongoDB Atlas. Perhaps update/provide a guide (in PDF) on how to use MongoDB Atlas instead. Fortunately, it wasn't as difficult to use MongoDB Atlas as they provide code snippet on how to connect to the database. However, some students may find it overwhelming if they are not familiar with using these cloud services and databases.

Thank you for this course, appreciate it!

response.content: Thanks for the very detailed review Choy!
response.content_html: Thanks for the very detailed review Choy!

results.content_html:
Before taking up this course, I have read reviews on both ends (5 stars, 2 stars & 1 star). While not everything is covered, I would say this course is meant to kickstart your learning and understanding of TDD and unit testing, especially if you are completely new. And I am confident to say that this course is well-scoped and suffice in building one's foundation and having a big picture.

After completing the course, it has helped to bridge some gaps and understanding of how unit testing works, especially in the area of mocking values. While my projects don't really just do CRUD operations, I am able to take actionable steps to apply what I have learnt into my projects. Considering that the Jest documentation can be quite foreign if you are new, going through this course let me go beyond to continue learning and understanding Jest and mocking in particular.

Feedback: Will be good to occasionally check if the services suggested to use is still applicable. For example, the DB cloud service used which is mLab, is now part of MongoDB Atlas. Perhaps update/provide a guide (in PDF) on how to use MongoDB Atlas instead. Fortunately, it wasn't as difficult to use MongoDB Atlas as they provide code snippet on how to connect to the database. However, some students may find it overwhelming if they are not familiar with using these cloud services and databases.

Thank you for this course, appreciate it!

response.content: Hey Curtis, I like to give examples that resemble real-world applications as much as possible. Most real-world REST API's use a database like MongoDB for example. We also learn how to mock MongoDB in our tests using an in-memory db later in the course.

results.content:
I actually like the flow of presented materials: it's simple and easy to follow, but I already have some knowledge what is test and how things working underneath. What is test runner and etc. for other people it might be not so "obvious".
But again - it's still easy for me to follow.

Can you please do "Acceptance test as well"? I would like to be notified if you have an Acceptance Testing course and I would definitely buy it.

response.content: Hey Dmytro, thanks for the feedback! About acceptance tests, they're basically requirements set from the product owner for a specific user story. Ie. a password must be at least 8 characters with 1 number and 1 capital letter. These can easily be converted into unit tests or automated tests.
response.content_html: Hey Dmytro, thanks for the feedback! About acceptance tests, they're basically requirements set from the product owner for a specific user story. Ie. a password must be at least 8 characters with 1 number and 1 capital letter. These can easily be converted into unit tests or automated tests.

results.content: This course was pretty good. I was looking for something that would literally walk through adding tests to and actual node project and we did that in this course. However, I do think it should be reiterated that this course is specifically for testing node API's not general node applications. Unfortunately there continues to be a dearth of information on that particular topic, however this course can potentially be a good way to get comfortable enough with testing that you can figure it out yourself.

results.content: It is a "short course"(only 3 hours) but it's worth it. It is one of the things I needed it. How to make test and tdd. I come from AngularJS/Angular camp, and despite I knew some NodeJS, one of the missing things I didn't know was to make tests. So, even If I am going to finish soon this course, I will watch it again many times because I want to learn it. Maybe the only thing I miss here is more explanation from the documentation.

The only thing missing here is a real-time demonstration of an actual application which uses this CRUD API. That would open up our minds even clearer.

results.content: Really bad and really disappointing. The videos are often cut mid sentence and there is no real learning path. The example application he is testing is a ToDo app with one model (with two static properties and no relationships), one controller and one route. Mocking is barely explained at all. I'm really convinced he knows how to test node applications. I watched about 60% of the course before I gave up completely. You can learn more by just reading docs and looking at code examples. Maybe I'll try a different course taught by someone else.
